description.heading: BACKGROUND OF THE INVENTION
description.p: The subject invention relates to a method according to the preamble of claim 1 and a system according to the preamble of claim 6.

Steering systems often have unwanted variations in the amount of steering torque that must be applied by a driver. One source is the phasing of the upper and lower cardan joints on an intermediate shaft. Cardan joints phasing imperfections will cause a cyclical variation in the steering torque applied by a driver that repeats every 180 degrees of the steering wheel. A goal in the design of any steering system is to eliminate, or at least minimize, unwanted steering torque variations that are felt by a driver. The best approach to eliminate these torque variations is to eliminate or minimize them at the source, however, due to various limitations and trade-offs, torque variations will always be present to some degree.
Document US 2003/042067 A1 discloses a method in accordance with the preamble of claim 1 and a control system in accordance with the preamble of claim 6.
It is an object of the present invention to provide an improved method and an improved system for controlling an electric power steering system.
description.heading: SUMMARY OF THE INVENTION
description.p: The object is satisfied by a method in accordance with the features of claim 1 and a control system in accordance with the features of claim 6. Preferred embodiments of the invention are described in the dependent claims.

A method of controlling an electric power steering system is provided. The method includes: determining a scale factor based on a handwheel position; applying the scale factor to a hand wheel torque value to scale the hand wheel torque value; and generating a corrected handwheel torque signal based on the scaled hand wheel torque value.

description.p: The foregoing and other features, and advantages of the invention are apparent from the following detailed description taken in conjunction with the accompanying drawings in which:

description.heading: DETAILED DESCRIPTION
description.p: The following description is merely exemplary in nature. It should be understood that throughout the drawings, corresponding reference numerals indicate like or corresponding parts and features.

Referring now to FIG. 1, where the invention will be described with reference to specific embodiments without limiting same, an exemplary embodiment of a vehicle 10 including a steering system 12 is illustrated. In various embodiments, the steering system 12 includes a hand wheel 14 coupled to a steering shaft 16. In one exemplary embodiment, the steering system 12 is an electric power steering (EPS) system that further includes a steering assist unit 18 that couples to the steering shaft 16 of the steering system 12 and to tie rods 20, 22 of the vehicle 10. The steering assist unit 18 includes, for example, a rack and pinion steering mechanism (not shown) that may be coupled through the steering shaft 16 to a steering actuator motor and gearing (hereinafter referred to as the steering actuator). During operation, as the hand wheel 14 is turned by a vehicle operator, the motor of the steering assist unit 18 provides the assistance to move the tie rods 20, 22 which in turn moves steering knuckles 24, 26, respectively, coupled to roadway wheels 28, 30, respectively of the vehicle 10. Although an EPS system is illustrated in FIG. 1 and described herein, it is appreciated that the steering system 12 of the present disclosure can include various controlled steering systems including, but not limited to, steering systems with hydraulic configurations, and steer by wire configurations.

As shown in FIG. 1, the vehicle 10 further includes various sensors 31, 32 that detect and measure observable conditions of the steering system 12 and/or of the vehicle 10. The sensors 31, 32 generate sensor signals based on the observable conditions. In various embodiments, the sensors 31, 32 can include, for example, a load sensor, a driver torque sensor, and/or a position sensor.

In various embodiments, a control module 40 controls the operation of the steering system 12 and/or the vehicle 10 based on one or more of the sensor signals and further based on the torque correction systems and methods of the present disclosure. Generally speaking, the torque correction systems and methods of the present disclosure reduce steering torque variation felt by a driver due to intermediate shaft phasing. For example, the systems and methods receive a handwheel angle signal from a position sensor which measures the handwheel angle and uses this information to modify the torque sensor signal and remove any harmonic variation in the output signal. Once implemented, the systems and methods allow a designer more flexibility in designing steering system geometry because the variation in handwheel torque due to the positioning of the steering system components may be removed analytically.

Referring now to FIG. 2 where a dataflow diagram illustrates exemplary embodiments of the control module 40 of FIG. 1 used to control the steering system 12 and/or the vehicle 10 of FIG. 1. In various embodiments, the control module 40 can include one or more sub-modules and datastores. As used herein the terms module and sub-module refer to an application specific integrated circuit (ASIC), an electronic circuit, a processor (shared, dedicated, or group) and memory that executes one or more software or firmware programs, a combinational logic circuit, and/or other suitable components that provide the described functionality. As can be appreciated, the sub-modules shown in FIG. 2 can be combined and/or further partitioned to similarly reduce steering torque variation. As can be appreciated, the sub-modules shown in FIG. 2 can be implemented as a single control module 40 (as shown) or multiple control modules (not shown). Inputs to the control module 40 can be generated from the sensors of the vehicle 10 (FIG. 1), can be modeled within the control module 40 (e.g., by other sub-modules (not shown)), can be received from other control modules (not shown), and/or can be predefined. In various embodiments, the control module 40 includes a scale factor determination module 50 and a handwheel torque determination module 52.

The scale factor determination module 50 receives as input a relative handwheel position 56. Based on the relative handwheel position 56, the scale factor determination module 50 determines a scale factor 54. In various embodiments, the scale factor determination module 50 determines the scale factor 54 (TorqCorrSclFctr) based on the following equation: TorqCorrSclFctr=1+TorqCorrMag*Cos⁢2*HwPosRel+TorqCorrPhase.

Where TorqCorrMag represents a torque correction magnitude. The TorqCorrPhase represents the torque correction phase. The correction magnitude and phase are based on analysis of cardan joint angles and geometry. In various embodiments, a wrapping function may be applied to the handwheel position to accommodate the range of degrees accepted by the cosine function.

In various embodiments, the scale factor determination module 50 performs a validity check before computing the scale factor 54. The scale factor determination module 50 evaluates one or more diagnostic trouble codes relating to the handwheel position 56. When a diagnostic trouble code has been set to TRUE, then the scale factor 54 may be set to a predetermined value (e.g., one, or any other value). Otherwise, when the diagnostic trouble code(s) are set to FALSE, then the scale factor 54 is determined as discussed above.

In another example, the scale factor determination module 50 may evaluate the status of other algorithms that affect the handwheel position 56. For example, when the other algorithms have completed, the scale factor 54 can be determined.

The handwheel torque determination module 52 receives as input a non-corrected handwheel torque 62 and the scale factor 54. In various embodiments, the non-corrected handwheel torque 62 can be estimated based on one or more algorithms. Based on the inputs, the handwheel torque determination module 52 generates a handwheel torque signal 64. For example, the handwheel torque determination module 52 determines a handwheel torque value based on the following equation: HwTrq=HwTrq*TorqCorrSclFctr.
The handwheel torque determination module 52 then generates the handwheel torque signal 64 based on the handwheel torque value.

Referring now to FIG. 3 and with continued reference to FIG. 2, a flow diagram illustrates a steering control method that can be performed by the control module 40 of FIG. 1. As can be appreciated in light of the disclosure, the order of operation within the method is not limited to the sequential execution as illustrated in FIG. 3, but may be performed in one or more varying orders as applicable and in accordance with the present disclosure.
As can be appreciated, the steering control method can be scheduled to run based on predetermined events and/or can run at scheduled intervals during operation of the vehicle 10 (FIG. 1).

In one example, the method may begin at 100. A validity check is performed at 105. If the validity check is true at 106, then the relative handwheel position 56 is received and processed at 110. For example, any necessary wrapping methods are performed on the handwheel position 56. The torque correction scale factor 54 is determined, for example, using equation 1 at 120. The torque correction scale factor 54 is applied to the handwheel torque 62, for example, using equation 2 at 130. The handwheel torque signal 64 is generated at 150. Thereafter, the method may end at 160.

If, however, at 105, the validity check is false, the torque correction scale factor 54 is set to a predetermined value at 140. The torque correction scale factor is applied to the handwheel torque 62, for example, using equation 2 at 130. The handwheel torque signal 64 is generated at 150. Thereafter, the method may end at 160.

claim.claim-text:
Verfahren zum Steuern eines elektrischen Servolenkungssystems (12), wobei das Verfahren umfasst, dass: ein Skalierungsfaktor (54) auf der Grundlage einer Lenkradposition (56) bestimmt wird (120); der Skalierungsfaktor (54) auf einen Lenkraddrehmomentwert (62) angewendet wird (130), um den Lenkraddrehmomentwert zu skalieren; und auf der Grundlage des skalierten Lenkraddrehmomentwerts ein korrigiertes Lenkraddrehmomentsignal (64) erzeugt wird (150),
dadurch gekennzeibchnet, dass das Verfahren ferner umfasst, dass eine Validitätsprüfung der Lenkradposition (56) durchgeführt wird (105) und dass das Bestimmen des Skalierungsfaktors (54) auf der Validitätsprüfung beruht.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1,
wobei das Durchführen (105) der Validitätsprüfung umfasst, dass mindestens ein Diagnoseproblemcode ausgewertet wird.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1,
wobei das Durchführen (105) der Validitätsprüfung umfasst, dass ausgewertet wird, ob mindestens ein Verfahren, das die Lenkradposition betrifft, abgeschlossen worden ist.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1,
wobei das Bestimmen (120) des Skalierungsfaktors (54) auf einer Drehmomentkorrekturphase und/oder einer Drehmomentkorrekturamplitude beruht.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1,
wobei die Drehmomentkorrekturamplitude und/oder die Drehmomentkorrekturphase auf einer Analyse von Winkeln und Geometrien von Kardangelenken beruht bzw. beruhen.

Steuerungssystem (40) für ein elektrisches Servolenkungssystem (12), umfassend: ein Skalierungsfaktor-Bestimmungsmodul (50), das einen Skalierungsfaktor (54) auf der Grundlage einer Lenkradposition (56) bestimmt; und ein Lenkraddrehmoment-Bestimmungsmodul (englisch: harmonic pinion torque correction) (52), das den Skalierungsfaktor (54) auf einen Lenkraddrehmomentwert (62) anwendet, um den Lenkraddrehmomentwert zu skalieren, und das ein korrigiertes Lenkraddrehmomentsignal (64) auf der Grundlage des skalierten Lenkraddrehmomentwerts erzeugt,
dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass das Skalierungsfaktor-Bestimmungsmodul (50) eine Validitätsprüfung der Lenkradposition (56) durchführt und den Skalierungsfaktor (54) auf der Grundlage der Validitätsprüfung bestimmt.

Steuerungssystem (40) nach Anspruch 6,
wobei das Skalierungsfaktor-Bestimmungsmodul (50) die Validitätsprüfung durchführt, indem es mindestens einen Diagnoseproblemcode auswertet.

Steuerungssystem (40) nach Anspruch 6,
wobei das Skalierungsfaktor-Bestimmungsmodul (50) die Validitätsprüfung durchführt, indem es auswertet, ob mindestens ein Verfahren, das die Lenkradposition betrifft, abgeschlossen worden ist.

Steuerungssystem (40) nach Anspruch 6,
wobei das Skalierungsfaktor-Bestimmungsmodul (50) den Skalierungsfaktor (52) auf der Grundlage einer Drehmomentkorrekturphase und/oder einer Drehmomentkorrekturamplitude bestimmt.

Steuerungssystem (40) nach Anspruch 9,
wobei die Drehmomentkorrekturamplitude und/oder die Drehmomentkorrekturphase auf der Analyse von Winkeln und Geometrien von Kardangelenken beruht bzw. beruhen.

System, umfassend: ein Lenkungssystem (12); und ein Steuerungssystem (40) nach einem beliebigen der Ansprüche 6 bis 10 mit einem Controller, der den Skalierungsfaktor (54) als Funktion der Lenkradposition (56) berechnet, der den Skalierungsfaktor (54) auf das Drehmomentsignal (62) anwendet, und der das Drehmomentsignal (62) für das Lenkungssystem (12) erzeugt.

System nach Anspruch 11,
wobei der Controller die Validitätsprüfung durchführt und den Skalierungsfaktor (54) auf der Grundlage der Validitätsprüfung bestimmt.

System nach Anspruch 12,
wobei der Controller die Validitätsprüfung durchführt, indem er mindestens einen Diagnoseproblemcode auswertet.

A method of controlling an electric power steering system (12), comprising: determining (120) a scale factor (54) based on a handwheel position (56); applying (130) the scale factor (54) to a hand wheel torque value (62) to scale the hand wheel torque value; and generating (150) a corrected handwheel torque signal (64) based on the scaled hand wheel torque value, characterized in that
the method further comprises performing (105) a validity check of the handwheel position (56) and that the determining of the scale factor (54) is based on the validity check.
The method of claim 1 wherein the performing (105) the validity check comprises evaluating at least one diagnostic trouble code.
The method of claim 1 wherein the performing (105) the validity check comprises evaluating whether at least one method relating to handwheel position has completed.
The method of claim 1 wherein the determining (120) the scale factor (54) is based on at least one of a torque correction phase and a torque correction magnitude.
The method of claim 1 wherein the at least one of the torque correction magnitude and the torque correction phase are based on analysis of cardan joint angles and geometry.

A control system (40) for an electric power steering system (12), comprising: a scale factor determination module (50) that determines a scale factor (54) based on a handwheel position (56); and a harmonic pinion torque correction (52) applies the scale factor (54) to a hand wheel torque value (62) to scale the hand wheel torque value, and that generates a corrected handwheel torque signal (64) based on the scaled hand wheel torque value, characterized in that
the scale factor determination module (50) performs a validity check of the handwheel position (56) and determines the scale factor (54) based on the validity check.
The control system (40) of claim 6 wherein the scale factor determination module (50) performs the validity check by evaluating at least one diagnostic trouble code.

The control system (40) of claim 6 wherein the scale factor determination module (50) performs the validity check by evaluating whether at least one method relating to handwheel position has completed.

The control system (40) of claim 6 wherein the scale factor determination module (50) determines the scale factor (52) based on at least one of a torque correction phase and a torque correction magnitude.
The control system (40) of claim 9 wherein the at least one of the torque correction magnitude and the torque correction phase are based on analysis of cardan joint angles and geometry.

A system comprising: a steering system (12); and a control system (40) according to anyone of claims 6 to 10 with a controller that computes the scale factor (54) as a function of the handwheel position (56), that applies the scale factor (54) to the torque signal (62), and that generates the torque signal (62) to the steering system (12).
The system of claim 11 wherein the controller performs the validity check and determines the scale factor (54) based on the validity check.
The system of claim 12 wherein the controller performs the validity check by evaluating at least one diagnostic trouble code.

Procédé pour commander un système de direction assistée électrique (12), comprenant les étapes consistant à : déterminer (120) un facteur d'échelle (54) sur la base d'une position d'un volant (56) ; appliquer (130) le facteur d'échelle (54) à une valeur du couple de volant (62) pour mettre à l'échelle la valeur du couple de volant ; et générer (150) un signal de couple de volant corrigé (64) sur la base de la valeur du couple de volant mise à l'échelle, caractérisé en ce que le procédé comprend en outre d'exécuter (105) une vérification de validité de la position du volant (56) et en ce que la détermination du facteur d'échelle (54) est basée sur la vérification de validité.
Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel l'exécution (105) de la vérification de validité comprend d'évaluer au moins un code de problème diagnostique.
Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel l'exécution (105) de la vérification de validité comprend d'évaluer si au moins un procédé en relation avec la position du volant est terminé.

Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel la détermination (120) du facteur d'échelle (54) est basée sur au moins un paramètre parmi une phase de correction de couple et une amplitude de correction de couple.

Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel ledit au moins un paramètre parmi l'amplitude de correction de couple et la phase de correction de couple est basé sur l'analyse des angles et de la géométrie des joints de cardan.

Système de commande (40) pour un système de direction assistée électrique (12), comprenant : un module de détermination de facteur d'échelle (50) qui détermine un facteur d'échelle (54) sur la base d'une position du volant (56) ; et une correction de couple de pignon harmonique (52) qui applique le facteur d'échelle (54) à une valeur du couple de volant (62) pour mettre à l'échelle la valeur du couple de volant, et qui génère un signal de couple de volant corrigé (64) sur la base de la valeur du couple de volant mise à l'échelle, caractérisé en ce que le module de détermination du facteur d'échelle (50) exécute une vérification de validité de la position du volant (56) et détermine le facteur d'échelle (54) sur la base de la vérification de validité.

Système de commande (40) selon la revendication 6, dans lequel le module de détermination du facteur d'échelle (50) exécute la vérification de validité en évaluant au moins un code de problème diagnostique.

Système de commande (40) selon la revendication 6, dans lequel le module de détermination du facteur d'échelle (50) exécute la vérification de validité en évaluant si au moins un procédé en relation avec la position du volant est terminé.

Système de commande (40) selon la revendication 6, dans lequel le module de détermination du facteur d'échelle (50) détermine le facteur d'échelle (52) sur la base d'au moins un paramètre parmi une phase de correction de couple et une amplitude de correction de couple.

Système de commande (40) selon la revendication 9, dans lequel ledit au moins un paramètre parmi l'amplitude de correction de couple et la phase de correction de couple est basé sur l'analyse des angles et de la géométrie des joints de cardan.

Système comprenant : un système de direction (12) ; et un système de commande (40) selon l'une quelconque des revendications 6 à 10 avec un contrôleur qui calcule le facteur d'échelle (54) en fonction de la position du volant (16), qui applique le facteur d'échelle (54) au signal de couple (62), et qui génère le signal de couple (62) vers le système de direction (12).
Système selon la revendication 11, dans lequel le contrôleur exécute la vérification de validité et détermine le facteur d'échelle (54) sur la base de la vérification de validité.
Système selon la revendication 12, dans lequel le contrôleur exécute la vérification de validité en évaluant au moins un code de problème diagnostique.
